name: Lima
fun_fact: Fun fact: Lima is the second-largest desert city in the world after Cairo, yet it never rains - the coastal fog (gar√∫a) creates perpetual grey skies from May to November, but ancient water canals built over 2,000 years ago by pre-Incan civilizations are still in use today.

hero_dishes.name: Ceviche
hero_dishes.description: Raw fish 'cooked' in lime juice with red onions, aj√≠ chili peppers, salt, and cilantro - served with sweet potato, choclo corn, and cancha (toasted corn)
hero_dishes.origin_story: Peru's national dish dates back to pre-Incan times when fishermen 'cooked' their catch in tumbo fruit juice. Modern ceviche uses lime (brought by Spanish) and was perfected in Lima. The crucial rule: eat it only at lunch when fish is freshest. Cevicher√≠as close by 4pm - if they're open late, walk away.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La Mar Cebicher√≠a by Gast√≥n Acurio in Miraflores (flagship restaurant of Peru), Punto Azul (beloved by locals, expect lines), Canta Rana in Barranco (classic pub-style institution since forever), or Al Toke Pez (off-the-beaten-path local favorite)

hero_dishes.name: Anticuchos
hero_dishes.description: Grilled beef heart skewers marinated in aj√≠ panca (Peruvian red chili), cumin, garlic, and vinegar - charred on the outside, tender inside, served with potatoes and spicy aj√≠ sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created by African slaves in colonial Lima who were given unwanted cuts like beef heart. They transformed this humble organ meat into Peru's most beloved street food using indigenous Andean spices. Now anticuchos are Peru's answer to yakitori - vendors set up charcoal grills on every street corner at sunset.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: T√≠o Mario in Barranco (with view of Bridge of Sighs), or street vendors across Lima who set up grills in late afternoon (look for the smoke and crowds)

hero_dishes.name: Lomo Saltado
hero_dishes.description: Stir-fried beef with tomatoes, onions, aj√≠ amarillo, soy sauce, served over french fries with rice - Peru's ultimate fusion dish
hero_dishes.origin_story: When Chinese immigrants arrived in 1849 to work plantations, they brought wok cooking techniques. Lime√±os added Peruvian beef, aj√≠ peppers, and tomatoes, creating this iconic chifa (Chinese-Peruvian) dish. The wok's high heat creates the essential 'sear' flavor, while fries absorb the savory sauce. It's on every menu from street stalls to fine dining.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Any chifa restaurant in Lima's Chinatown (Barrio Chino), Surquillo Market food stalls, or upscale versions at restaurants like Central

hero_dishes.name: Causa Lime√±a
hero_dishes.description: Layered terrine of yellow potato pur√©e with aj√≠ amarillo and lime, filled with chicken or tuna salad, avocado, and topped with hard-boiled eggs and olives
hero_dishes.origin_story: During Peru's war with Chile (1879-1884), women sold this potato dish to raise funds for 'la causa' (the cause) - hence the name. The dish showcases Peru's 4,000+ potato varieties and African, Spanish, and indigenous fusion. The bright yellow color comes from aj√≠ amarillo, Peru's most essential chili.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La Mar, Canta Rana, or most cevicher√≠as as a cold appetizer

signature_drinks.name: Pisco Sour
signature_drinks.description: Peru's national cocktail made with pisco (grape brandy), lime juice, simple syrup, egg white, and Angostura bitters
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Lime√±os debate endlessly whether Peruvian or Chilean pisco is superior (it's Peru, obviously). The drink was invented in 1920s Lima by American bartender Victor Morris. It's served before lunch or at evening cocktail hour. The egg white creates signature foam, the bitters are dotted on top in artistic patterns. Never order just one.

signature_drinks.name: Chicha Morada
signature_drinks.description: Purple corn drink made by boiling purple maize with pineapple, cinnamon, cloves, and lime - sweet, refreshing, and naturally vibrant purple
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: This pre-Columbian drink is Peru's answer to soda - served ice-cold at every cevicher√≠a and home meal. The purple corn (ma√≠z morado) is native to the Andes and packed with antioxidants. Street vendors sell it from large glass jugs. It's the traditional pairing with ceviche.

food_culture_notes: Lima won 'World's Leading Culinary Destination' at 2023 World Travel Awards - gastronomic capital of Latin America
Ceviche timing is sacred: only eat it at lunch (11am-4pm) when fish is freshest from morning catch
Surquillo Market is where locals shop - explore fruits like lucuma, chirimoya, and aguaymanto you've never seen elsewhere
Nikkei cuisine (Japanese-Peruvian fusion) is huge in Lima - Japanese immigrants brought techniques that merged with Peruvian ingredients

landmarks: Plaza Mayor (Plaza de Armas) with Cathedral of Lima and Government Palace - Francisco Pizarro founded the city here in 1535
Huaca Pucllana - 1,500-year-old adobe pyramid in the middle of Miraflores neighborhood
Barranco's Bridge of Sighs (Puente de los Suspiros) and colorful bohemian streets
Real Felipe Fortress - built to defend against pirates including Sir Francis Drake (1579)
atmosphere: Perpetual grey fog (gar√∫a) May-November, sunny December-April
Black vultures (gallinazos) circling overhead cleaning the city
Pacific Ocean waves at Costa Verde, Punta Hermosa - surfers catch morning sets before work
10 million people (one-third of Peru's population) creating South America's second-largest city
colors: grey fog and mist during gar√∫a season
bright yellow from aj√≠ amarillo and causa

Yellow underwear worn on New Year's Eve for good luck
